sec.title: Objective
sec.p: To assess quality-of-life outcomes in patients undergoing nasal tip surgery with the vertical dome division technique using validated instruments (Rhinoplasty Outcome Evaluation [ROE] and Nasal Obstruction Symptom Evaluation [NOSE]).

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: Case series with planned data collection.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: Tertiary university center.

sec.title: Subject and Methods
sec.p: Patients undergoing primary cosmetic and functional rhinoseptoplasty using vertical dome division were consecutively evaluated. The ROE, NOSE, and 100-mm visual analog scale (VAS) were administered pre- and postoperatively.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Forty-four patients were included and completed pre- and postoperative questionnaires. Their median age was 28 years, 27 (61%) were female, and the median duration of follow-up was 5 months (range, 3-9 months). Median postoperative ROE, NOSE, and VAS scores (79 [66; 87], 20 [15; 23], and 88 [61; 97], respectively) showed significant improvement compared with preoperative scores (29 [16; 41], 75 [60; 95], and 65 [46; 82], respectively; P < .001). The change in median ROE score was significantly greater in normal- and thin-skinned patients than in thick-skinned patients (54 vs 33; P = .033). Median changes in NOSE-p (−48.5 vs −68.0; P = .10) and VAS (69.0 vs 48.0; P =.083) scores did not differ between normal-/thin- and thick-skinned patients.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Vertical dome division is a versatile technique for nasal tip refinement that resulted in significant improvement in quality-of-life outcomes related to rhinoplasty and nasal obstruction, as well as satisfaction with nasal appearance in a short-term follow-up period. The vertical dome division technique does not seem to be indicated only in patients with thick skin.

body.p: In rhinoplasty, the nasal tip presents a major challenge to the surgeon.1,2 Many options are available to achieve satisfactory results, and the choice of an appropriate surgical technique should be based on the patient’s characteristics and the surgeon’s skill. Vertical dome division (VDD) is a versatile technique that can be used when nasal tip rotation, narrowing, symmetry restoration, and changes in projection are indicated. Goldman3 first described VDD in the 1950s, and the technique has since been modified to create an approach with minimal tissue excision that is focused on the incision and mobilization of the lower lateral cartilages (LLCs).4-7 The Simons5 modification of VDD differs from the Goldman technique in that it preserves intact the underlying bridge of skin and mucosa and uses permanent nylon sutures to approximate and influence the rotation of the medial crura.

Although VDD can be considered a conservative, cartilage-sparing approach to nasal tip surgery,8 concerns about postoperative asymmetry and cartilage visibility remain, especially in thin-skinned patients. Some surgeons prefer to use the Simons modification of VDD only in thick-skinned or ethnic patients,2,8 whereas others also, or even more frequently, use it in thin-skinned patients. Several publications have addressed these issues in describing the surgical technique and its modifications, indications, complications, and reoperation rates.4-7 However, little effort has been made to study patients’ satisfaction and quality-of-life outcomes after VDD surgery using validated scales.

This study aimed to evaluate satisfaction and quality-of-life outcomes in patients undergoing the Simons modification of VDD using the Rhinoplasty Outcome Evaluation (ROE)9 and Portuguese version of the Nasal Obstruction Symptom Evaluation (NOSE-p)10,11 and to compare these outcomes between thick-skinned and thin- or normal-skinned patients.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: A consecutive sample of patients undergoing primary rhinoseptoplasty at a tertiary university center in southern Brazil between December 2010 and October 2011 was evaluated for eligibility. The research protocol was approved by the Ethics and Research Committee of the Hospital de Clinicas de Porto Alegre (No. 10-420). All eligible patients were informed about the study and provided written consent.

Eligible participants were aged ≥16 years, had nasal obstruction symptoms, and were candidates for functional and esthetic primary rhinoseptoplasty. Exclusion criteria were (1) no nasal tip concern, (2) previous nasal surgery, (3) turbinate hypertrophy as the sole cause of nasal obstruction, and/or (4) concomitant procedures, such as functional endoscopic sinus surgery, adenoidectomy, blepharoplasty, or otoplasty.

The patients were classified according to observed skin thickness intraoperatively. A patient was considered to be thick skinned if nasal tip definition was limited by excessive overlying soft tissue. If the nasal tip had thin overlying soft tissue, raising a concern about cartilage visibility, the patient was considered to be thin skinned. If nasal skin thickness did not raise any concern during surgery, the patient was considered to be normal skinned.

sec.title: Surgical Procedure
sec.p: A single surgeon (M.L.-W.) performed all surgeries with the assistance of medical residents. All procedures used an endonasal rhinoplasty technique with the Simon modification of VDD5,6 to treat nasal tip deformities. The LLCs were delivered by marginal incision combined with an intercartilaginous incision. The natural domal high point was determined by inserting a hook behind the soft-tissue facet, impaling the anatomical apex of the LLC. After delivery, the LLC was cleaned of overlying soft tissue and then vertically divided on either side of the apex to resect a variable portion of the medial and lateral crura, generally no more than 2 mm. The vestibular skin and mucosa were preserved7 (Figure 1). A cartilaginous strut was placed sagittally between the medial crura, and a 5-0 clear nylon suture was used to fix it in position and bring together the medial crural ends. In most cases, a small cephalic trim was also performed. No attempt was made to reconstitute the dome by suturing the medial to the lateral cut ends. After nasal tip surgery was completed, appropriate dorsal profile alignment was achieved. All patients underwent lateral and medial osteotomies.

caption.p: Schematics of the vertical dome division technique. The lower lateral cartilages were delivered and the natural domal high point was determined. The cartilages were vertically divided, removing a variable portion of the medial and lateral crura. The vestibular skin was preserved.

sec.p: In addition to septoplasty, patients were randomly allocated to undergo or not undergo inferior turbinate reduction, as part of an ongoing randomized clinical trial that is not described in this article.

sec.title: Outcome Measures
sec.p: The ROE scale9 (Table 1) was administered to all patients preoperatively and postoperatively. This scale is composed of 6 questions in 3 quality-of-life domains: physical, mental/emotional, and social (Figure 2). Each question is scored from 0 to 4 on a Likert-type scale, and total scores are converted to range from 0 to 100 by dividing by 24 and multiplying by 100. For questions 1 to 3 and 5, 0 indicates “not at all” and 4 indicates “completely.” For question 4, 0 indicates “always” and 4 indicates “never.” For question 6, 0 represents “definitely” and 4 represents “no.”9,12 Higher scores indicate greater satisfaction, and a score of 0 represents major dissatisfaction. A 100-mm visual analog scale (VAS) was also used to evaluate satisfaction with nasal appearance (0 mm = extremely unsatisfied, 100 mm = extremely satisfied) preoperatively and postoperatively.

tr.td: 1. How well do you like the appearance of your nose?
2. How well are you able to breathe through your nose?
3. How much do you feel your friends and loved ones like your nose?
4. Do you think your current nasal appearance limits your social or professional activities?
5. How confident are you that your nasal appearance is the best that it can be?
6. Would you like to surgically alter the appearance or function of your nose?

caption.p: Box whisker plots of (A) Rhinoplasty Outcomes Evaluation (ROE), (B) Nasal Obstruction Symptom Evaluation–Portuguese (NOSE-p), and (C) 100-mm visual analog scale scores before and after vertical dome division surgery. P < .001 for all comparisons.

sec.p: Functional outcomes were assessed by the Portuguese version of the NOSE, a quality-of-life questionnaire.11 This instrument is composed of 5 obstruction-related items addressing the severity of a patient’s complaints within the past month, with reference to each of the following: (1) “nasal congestion or stuffiness,” (2) “nasal blockage or obstruction,” (3) “trouble breathing through my nose,” (4) “trouble sleeping,” and (5) “unable to get enough air through my nose during exercise or exertion.”11,13 Each of the 5 items is scored using a 6-point Likert-type scale, as follows: 0, not a problem; 1, very mild problem; 2, moderate problem; 3, fairly bad problem; and 4, severe problem. Total scores are scaled to range from 0 to 100 by multiplying raw scores by 5, with higher scores indicating greater severity of problems related to nasal obstruction.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Normally distributed variables are described using means and standard deviations (SDs) and were analyzed using 2-tailed paired t tests. Nonparametric variables are described using medians and interquartile ranges and were compared using Mann-Whitney and Wilcoxon T tests. Outcomes were described as changes in score (postoperative – preoperative) or as the standardized response mean (SRM), which is defined as the change in score divided by its SD.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Forty-four of 77 evaluated patients were included in the study. Thirty-three patients did not meet the eligibility criteria, mainly because of previous nasal surgery (n = 8), esthetic complaints only (absence of nasal obstruction symptoms; n = 9), or lack of nasal tip concerns (n = 6). The study population included predominantly Caucasian subjects. Their median age was 28 (range, 17-64) years, and 27 (61%) patients were female. Preoperative patient characteristics are shown in Table 2.

All patients underwent rhinoseptoplasty with VDD, as described above. Inferior turbinate reduction was performed in 21 (48%) patients. All participants completed pre- and postoperative questionnaires, except for 1 patient who was lost to follow-up. The median duration of follow-up was 5 (range, 3-9) months.

Figure 2 shows the distribution of pre- and postoperative ROE, NOSE-p, and VAS scores (minimum, 25th percentile; median, 75th percentile; and maximum). Median postoperative ROE, NOSE-p, and VAS scores (79 [66; 87], 20 [15; 23], and 88 [61;97], respectively) showed significant improvement compared with preoperative scores (29 [16; 41], 75 [60; 95], and 65 [46; 82] respectively; P < .001). Changes in median ROE, NOSE-p, and VAS scores were similar among participants who underwent rhinoseptoplasty with and without inferior turbinate reduction (54 vs 44, P = .166; −50 vs −58.5, P = .114; and 66 vs 70, P = .923, respectively). ROE score, used to assess satisfaction with rhinoplasty, and ROE and VAS scores, used to assess satisfaction with rhinoplasty, had SRMs of 2.47 (95% confidence interval [CI], 2.16; 2.78) and 0.52 (95% CI 0.21; 0.82), respectively.

The change in median ROE score was significantly greater in normal- and thin-skinned patients than in thick-skinned patients (54 vs 33; P = .033). Changes in median NOSE-p (−48.5 vs −68.0; P = .10) and VAS (69.0 vs 48.0; P = .083) scores did not differ significantly between these groups (Figure 3).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The VDD technique can be used to treat asymmetrical, over- or underprojected, broad, and/or underrotated nasal tips. According to Simons’ 30 years of experience with this technique, patients with poorly projected nasal tips, marked bifidity, heavy skin, and vertical displacement of the LLCs are most likely to benefit from VDD.8

In this study, patients’ initial mean ROE and VAS scores were low and initial NOSE-p scores were high, demonstrating that nasal aspects negatively affected their preoperative quality of life. Rhinoseptoplasty using the VDD technique resulted in significant improvement in all of these scores in the short-term follow-up period.

Despite several research efforts,14,15 studies evaluating quality-of-life outcomes after nasal tip surgery with VDD remain scarce in the facial plastic surgery literature. To our knowledge, this study is the second to evaluate quality-of-life outcomes in patients undergoing VDD surgery. In 2011, Salari and Totonchi16 reported results from a randomized clinical trial comparing the Goldman and suture techniques for nasal tip surgery. The authors used a modified ROE scale that focused on patients’ satisfaction with nasal tip appearance. After 16 months of follow-up, they found that the Goldman technique yielded better results (improvement in modified ROE score by 49 vs 23; P < .01). Although our surgeries were performed using the Simons modification of VDD rather than the Goldman technique, and we used the original ROE instrument, postoperative ROE scores were comparable between studies.

A few other studies have used the ROE scale to evaluate postoperative outcomes following surgeries that did not use VDD. Arima et al17 reported a mean postoperative ROE score (76 ± 19.5) very similar to ours in patients who underwent rhinoplasty to correct crooked nose. Patients who underwent secondary rhinoplasty18 had a mean long-term postoperative ROE score of 59, which is considerably lower than our postoperative scores. This difference can probably be explained by the difficulty in achieving patient satisfaction inherent to secondary surgery.

Although the Goldman technique3 has been stigmatized since the 1950s, VDD has regained popularity and acceptance because of subsequently introduced modifications.4,5,7 Even so, experience with VDD differs among surgeons, and some strictly avoid it because of concerns about functional and esthetic postoperative results. Surgeons with more experience in the technique have expressed the main concern of potential asymmetry and cartilage visibility in thin-skinned patients, in contrast to the concern of potentially unnatural appearance experience by less-experienced surgeons.8

Nasal tip bossae, a recognized complication of rhinoplasty, involves asymmetry due to irregular knuckling or prominence of the alar cartilage. Some authors have suggested that the use of interrupted strip techniques in thin-skinned patients and VDD without suture reconstitution of the intact lateral crural strip cause postoperative bossae.19 However, Gillman et al19 demonstrated in a multivariate analysis that VDD with suture binding of medial crural elements reduced the risk of postoperative nasal tip bossae compared with complete strip techniques. They identified thin skin, instead of interrupted strip techniques, as an independent risk factor that increased the risk of postoperative bossae development almost 6-fold. Among thin-skinned patients, VDD and complete strip procedures were associated with similar risks of bossae development.19

Our data showed that thin- and normal-skinned patients were more satisfied (higher ROE score) with the outcome of surgery than were thick-skinned patients in the short-term follow-up period. This finding is in agreement with the argument that thin skin, although associated with a higher risk of nasal tip bossae development,19 is also associated with better outcomes20 irrespective of VDD use.19

Some limitations of this study should be considered. The first and most important limitation is the short follow-up period, as complications of surgery using VDD can occur in the long term. In addition, although the instruments used in the present study were able to capture quality-of-life outcomes related to rhinoplasty and nasal obstruction, they were not validated specifically for the assessment of nasal tip surgery outcomes. Despite these limitations, our results add relevant quality-of-life data to the rhinoplasty literature, including specific information about the outcomes of VDD surgery in Caucasian patients and a comparison of these outcomes according to skin thickness. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods can be developed and conducted on the basis of our findings.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: VDD is a versatile technique for nasal tip refinement that resulted in significant improvement in quality-of-life outcomes related to rhinoplasty and nasal obstruction, as well as satisfaction with nasal appearance in a short-term follow-up period. The VDD technique does not appear to be indicated in only patients with thick skin, as thin- and normal-skinned patients were more satisfied with the outcome of surgery than were thick-skinned patients. Long-term follow-up studies should be conducted to confirm these findings.
